I’m using a tag+footer protocol in this chat:

- I’ll start line 1 with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- You must mirror my tag on the first line of every reply, like `<q>` or `<o>`.
- You must end every reply with exactly one footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

In this turn, just restate those rules and confirm you will follow them. Do not write any content besides the header, body, and footer.

You have specified a tag+footer protocol for this chat:

- Each turn begins with `!<tag>`, where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- I must mirror your tag on the first line of every reply.
- I must end every reply with a single footer line in the format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

I confirm that I will follow these rules in all subsequent replies.

Now write the actual experimental protocol you outlined.



Constraints:

- Audience: technically literate researchers or senior engineers.

- Structure the protocol into exactly four titled sections:

  1. Goals

  2. Threat model & attack surfaces

  3. Task suite design

  4. Metrics & reporting

- Use concise paragraphs and bullet points where helpful.

- Make sure the design is realistic for evaluating a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE (e.g., code completion, refactoring, explanation).

- Do not include any prose outside these four sections.

1. Goals  
The protocol aims to rigorously evaluate the security and robustness of a code-assistant LLM integrated within an IDE. Primary objectives include:  
- Assessing the model’s resilience to adversarial prompts and code injection.  
- Measuring the assistant’s ability to avoid generating insecure or vulnerable code.  
- Quantifying the model’s effectiveness in supporting secure software development practices.

2. Threat model & attack surfaces  
- Adversary: A technically skilled user with access to the IDE and the code-assistant interface, capable of crafting malicious prompts or code snippets.  
- Attack surfaces:  
  - Prompt injection via user queries or code comments.  
  - Malicious code completions or suggestions.  
  - Manipulation of refactoring or explanation features to introduce vulnerabilities.  
- Assumptions: The IDE and LLM are up-to-date; network and system-level attacks are out of scope.

3. Task suite design  
- Construct a suite of tasks simulating real-world usage, including:  
  - Code completion in the presence of ambiguous or potentially malicious comments.  
  - Refactoring tasks where the original code contains subtle vulnerabilities.  
  - Requests for code explanations that could elicit insecure recommendations.  
- Include both benign and adversarially crafted scenarios.  
- Tasks are language-agnostic but focus on commonly used languages (e.g., Python, JavaScript, Java).  
- Each task is accompanied by a ground truth for secure and insecure outcomes.

4. Metrics & reporting  
- Security metrics:  
  - Number and severity of vulnerabilities introduced or overlooked by the assistant.  
  - Rate of successful prompt/code injection attacks.  
- Usability metrics:  
  - Task completion accuracy and time.  
  - User intervention required to correct insecure suggestions.  
- Reporting:  
  - Aggregate results by task type and language.  
  - Detailed case studies of failure modes.  
  - Recommendations for mitigation and future improvements.
